name: "Swallows and Amazons" Part 1 Online Quiz | Kid Lit Authors L - Z | 15 Questions

questions.text: At which farm house were the Walker family staying at the start of the holiday in the Lake District?
questions.explanation:
Holly Howe.

	Holly Howe is based on a real place. The field leading down to the lake is even steeper than you might imagine.

questions.text: Which of the children had written the longest letter to their father when they asked if they could camp on the island?
questions.explanation:
Titty.

	Roger's letter was very short - "Please, daddy, may I too? With love. Roger". Susan didn't write a letter at all. Their mother had written even more than Titty but the children don't know what she said.

questions.text: On the Ship's Articles that they make up for Swallow what rank does Roger get rated at?
questions.explanation:
Ship's Boy.

	Yes, Roger really does start at the lowest rank. In later books he works his way up to able-seaman. He is delighted when the youngest Walker, Bridget, joins the crew in "Secret Water" for that means he is no longer at the bottom.

questions.text: Who does their mother pretend to be when helping to supervise the preparations for the first voyage to the island?
questions.explanation:
Queen Elizabeth I.

	Mrs. Walker is always ready to enter into the spirit of their adventures but is also always sensible about their preparations. She seems like the ideal parent.

questions.text: Which famous book did Titty take with her to the island?
questions.explanation:
"Robinson Crusoe " by Daniel Defoe.

	Later in "Swallows and Amazons" Titty uses her imagination to invent her own Robinson Crusoe life-style on the island. When her mother comes to visit she joins in with Titty's creative play.

questions.text: Which song did they sing as they set sail for the island?
questions.explanation:
Spanish Ladies.

	Lots of times during the stories the children sing sea shanties. Susan points out that they are really setting out "from" England and not towards England as "Spanish Ladies" definitely suggests.

questions.text: Who is the first of the Walker children to land on the island?
questions.explanation:
Roger.

	"She had hardly touched before Roger had jumped ashore with the painter."  The painter is the rope they will use to tie Swallow up for safety. Roger in the bows of the Swallow always sees it as his duty to be first to land. Susan is the second person ashore on this occasion.

questions.text: On which side of the island is the harbour?
questions.explanation:
south.

	The map in the end papers shows you the position of Wild Cat island. There is a compass symbol that confirms what Arthur Ransome describes as they sail around the island for the first time.

questions.text: From which farm do the children fetch the milk every morning?
questions.explanation:
Dixon's Farm.

	As soon as they wake up each day on the island the Swallows have to decide who is going to row across to Dixon's Farm for the milk. They usually row across because sailing would take too long. Mrs. Dixon is very friendly but Mr. Dixon is shy.

questions.text: What did they decide to call the nearby island which had nothing on it but rocks and heather and two dead trees?
questions.explanation:
Cormorant Island.

	They name the island after the cormorants that they see fishing there when they get a little closer. Sadly it has been reported that the real island upon which Cormorant Island is based is no longer visited by cormorants.

questions.text: What did Roger and Titty call it when they used to dive to the bottom of the lake and pick up little stones?
questions.explanation:
Diving for pearls.

	It was exciting finding the shining stones. "The worst of it was as soon as the stones were dry - and they dried quickly in the sun - they stopped shining, and could not be counted as pearls anymore."

questions.text: What sort of fish did Roger nearly catch when he shouted out, "It's a shark!"?
questions.explanation:
A pike.

	Arthur Ransome was fascinated by fishing. He wrote lots of stories about this favourite activity. Perhaps the most exciting fishing scene in this series comes in "The Big Six".

questions.text: What do the Walker children actually do when it says "they careened Swallow"?
questions.correct: They take the boat out of the water and scrub its bottom.
options: They fill it full of supplies for a new journey.
They set up the sails and ropes in a new way.
They tie it up to a motor boat so it can be towed along.
questions.explanation:
They take the boat out of the water and scrub its bottom.

	Careening is another idea that they probably got from pirate stories. After a long time in the water barnacles and weeds could attach themselves to the wood and slow down the boat when it sailed. This happened a lot in the waters around the West Indies.

questions.text: What did John really want when he asked in the shop for "grog"?
questions.explanation:
Ginger beer.

	John has got so involved in the chase after the pirate yacht Amazon that he is still living in his imagination. Susan is nearby and saves the situation.

questions.text: What did Roger find lying in the grass the day that the Amazons attacked the camp?
questions.explanation:
a big clasp knife.

	Of course Nancy blames Peggy for losing the ship's knife. "Peggy, you donkey..."
